titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Mathew Carey (1760-1839) was an important Philadelphia publisher and bookseller. He was born in Dublin, Ireland, and settled in Philadelphia in 1784. He founded the Pennsylvania Herald in 1785, and the Columbian Magazine in 1786. In the 1790s Carey went on to develop a successful publishing house, which printed the works of Thomas Jefferson, Parson Weems, Sir Walter Scott, and James Fenimore Cooper, as well as the first quarto Bible of American manufacture, in both the Douay version and the Authorized version.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 169 volumes of newspaper clippings compiled by Mathew Carey. The clippings are drawn from various sources, but nearly all are unattributed, and many are undated. Most volumes are miscellanies, but some are devoted to a single subject. Subjects include: law, internal improvements, politics, manufactures, sedition, medicine, education, and poetry. Many of the volumes are selectively indexed.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Library Company of Philadelphia: various Mathew Carey papers and collections.
